title-group.article-title: "Spectacles fashioned with such perspective art": A Phenomenological Reading of Webster's "The White Devil"

ref.mixed-citation: John Webster, The IVhite Devil, ed. John Russell Brown, The Revels Plays (Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard Univ. Press, 1960).
Edmund Husserl's Ideas, trans. W. R. Boyce Gibson (London: Allen and Unwin, 1967)
Richard M. Zaner, The Way of Phenomenology (Indianapolis: Bobbs-Merrill, 1970), Chs. 2 and 3.
"John Webster," Nineteenth Century, 19 [1886], 875

Peter Haworth says that "Webster's morality is of the same noble type as that which Sidney puts forward in his Apologia" (English Hymns and Ballads and Other Studies in Popular Literature [Oxford: Black- well, 1927], p. 73).
F. P. Wilson, a Christian universe is the basic assumption underlying Webster's world (Elizabethan and Jacobean [Oxford: Oxford Univ. Press, 1945], p. 7).
David Cecil declares, "His vision is a moral one. Webster sees life as a struggle between right and wrong" (Poets and Story-tellers [New York: Macmillan, 1949], p. 297).
Irving Ribner, Webster is a moralist who does not preach but "bases his faith upon human integrity" (Jacobean Tragedy: The Quest for Moral Order [London: Methuen, 1962], p. 100).

Joseph Henry Stodder, "regardless of how attached we become to Vittoria, our moral values never become distorted" (Moral Perspec- tive in Webster's Major Tragedies [Salzburg: Institut fur Englische Sprache und Literatur, 1974], p. 5)

Anders Dallby, Webster's vision, though "profoundly pessimistic," is lightened by the "way to salvation through repentance" (The Anatomy of Evil: A Study of John Webster's "The White Devil'' [Lund: Gleerup, 1974], p. 206).
E. M. W. Tillyard, The Elizabethan World Picture (New York: Macmillan, 1944), p. 18.
Charles Lamb, Specimens of English Dramatic Poets Who Lived About the Time of Shakespeare (London: Moxon, 1835), p. 247.
"Lectures on the Dramatic Literature of the Age of Elizabeth," in The Collected Works of William Hazlitt, ed. A. R. Waller and Arnold Glover, Vol. V [London: J. M. Dent, 1902], p. 241
Plays and Puritans and Other Historical Essays [London: Macmillan, 1873], p. 50
"The Function of Imagery in Webster," PMLA, 70 [1955], 717-39
Una Ellis-Fermor (The Jacobean Drama [London: Methuen, 1936], pp. 170—73)
Gunnar Boklund (The Sources of The White Devil' [Uppsala: Lundequistska, 1957], p. 177).
Ian Jack, "The Case of John Webster," Scrutiny, 16 (1949), 41.
T. S. Eliot, Webster's world is "directed toward chaos" ("Four Elizabethan Dramatists," in Elizabethan Essays [London: Faber, 1934], p. 19)

M. C. Bradbrook "the impression of the parts [constituting The White Devil] conflicts with the impression of the whole" (Themes and Conventions of Elizabethan Tragedy[1935; rpt. Cambridge: Cambridge Univ. Press, 1969], p. 194
Clifford Leech, there is an "absence of order in Webster's universe" (John Webster [London: Hogarth, 1951], p. 35)
Travis Bogard, it is "an immense jungle" (The Tragic Satire of John Webster [Berkeley: Univ. of California Press, 1955], p. 79)
Robert Ornstein, totally irrational (The Moral Vision of Jacobean Tragedy [Madison: Univ. of Wisconsin Press, 1960], pp. 133—35)
Don D. Moore, the play "goes in too many directions and taxes us" and "there is some blurring of characters" (John Webster and His Critics [Baton Rouge: Louisiana State Univ. Press, 1966], p. 164).
Death and Elizabethan Tragedy [Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard Univ. Press, 1936], p. 254
Fredson Bowers argues that Webster's characters are neither black nor white but gray (Elizabethan Revenge Tragedy, 1587-1642 [Princeton: Princeton Univ. Press, 1940], p. 180)

F. L. Lucas compares Vittoria with Macbeth and Milton's Satan: all three are wicked but win our sympathy because of their "magnificence" (Introduction to The White Devil by John Webster [London: Chatto and Windus, 1958], p. 37).
Rupert Brooke, John Webster and the Elizabethan Drama (London: Sidgwick and Jackson, 1916), p. 121.
Robert F. Whitman, "The Moral Paradox of Webster's Tragedy," PMLA, 90 (1975), 894-903.
B. J. Layman, "The Equilibrium of Opposites in The White Devil: A Reinterpretation," PMLA, 74 (1959), 337
Edwin B. Benjamin, "Patterns of Morality in The White Devil," English Studies, 46 (1965), 1-14.
T. B. Tomlinson, A Study of Elizabethan and Jacobean Tragedy (London: Cambridge Univ. Press, 1964), pp. 234-35.
Roma Gill, " 'Quaintly done': A Reading of The White Devil," Essays and Studies (1966)
The Elizabethan Dumb-Show: The History of a Dramatic Convention [Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard Univ. Press, 1966], p. 141
Ideas, p. 101.
Kurt Koffka, Principles of G est alt Psychology (New York: Harcourt, 1935), p. 393.
Martin Heidegger, Being and Time, trans. John Macquarrie and Edward Robinson (New York: Harper and Row, 1962), pp. 65ff.
William A. Luijpen, Existential Phenomenology (Pittsburgh: Duquesne Univ. Press, 1969), p. 78.
Pierre Thevenaz, What is Phenomenologyf and Other Essays, ed. and trans. James M. Edie (Chicago: Quadrangle, 1962), p. 99.
Benjamin, p. 10.
T. S. Eliot, Selected Prose, ed. John Hayward (Harmondsworth: Penguin, 1953), p. 109
Avi Erlich, Hamlet's Absent Father (Princeton: Princeton Univ. Press, 1977), Ch. 3.
Mehl, p. 141.
R. W. Dent, John Webster's Borrowing (Berkeley: Univ. of California Press, 1960), p. 157.
Maxine Sheets, The Phenomenology of Dance (Madison: The Univ. of Wisconsin Press, 1966), p. 11.
Norman N. Holland, "Unity Identity Text Self," PMLA, 90 (1975), 816.
Richard M. Zaner, "On the Sense of Method in Phenomenology," in Phenomenology and Philosoph- ical Understanding, ed. Edo Pivcevic (Cambridge: Cambridge Univ. Press, 1975), p. 127.
Ibid.
Thomas J. Hines, The Later Poetry of Wallace Stevens: Phenomenological Parallels With Husserl and Heidegger (Lewisburg, Pa.: Bucknell Univ. Press, 1976), p. 86.
Roger Stilling, Love and Death in Renaissance Tragedy (Baton Rouge: Louisiana State Univ. Press, 1976), p. 231.

"A True Relation of the Last Sickness and Death of Cardinal Bellarmine Who Died in Rome the Seventeenth Day of September 1621," in The Art of Dying Well by Robert Bellarmine (1622; rpt. London: Scolar Press, 1976), p. 387.
P. R., The Art to Die Well, Or a Brief and Easy Method How to Direct One's Life, to a Secure and Happy End (1626; rpt. London: Scolar Press, 1973), p. 291.
Paul Ricoeur, Husserl: An Analysis of His Phenomenology (Evanston, 111.: Northwestern Univ. Press, 1967), p. 9.
Ideas, p. 143.
M. Merleau-Ponty, Phenomenology of Perception, trans. Colin Smith (London: Routledge, 1974), p. 53.
Quentin Lauer, Introduction to Phenomenology and the Crisis of Philosophy by Edmund Husserl, trans. Quentin Lauer (New York: Harper and Row, 1965), p. 63.
Ideas, p. 200.
Ibid., p. 168.
